    • Method Detail

      • test

        public boolean test(@Nullable
                    Object value)
        Description copied from interface: Describer

        Validate if this describer is applicable to the given type. As the method gets the object to describe you might also distinguish if a Describer is applicable by the concrete value.

        Mind that an evaluation should be lightweight and should not depend on any mutable state of the object. This is because test() might be called multiple times (expect two times) for the same object.

        Specified by:
        test in interface Describer
        Specified by:
        test in interface Predicate<Object>
        Parameters:
        value - object to validate
        Returns:
        true if this describer can describe the given value; false otherwise

      • describeTo

        public void describeTo(@NotNull
                       Appendable appendable,
                       @Nullable
                       Object value,
                       int maxCount)
        Description copied from interface: Describer

        Add the description of the object to the given appendable.

        On implementation it is recommended to use for example Objects.requireNonNull(Object) to validate the appendable and to use Describer.validatedValue(Object) to validate that the object really matches the requirements - just in case someone did not call Describer.test(Object) before.

        Specified by:
        describeTo in interface Describer
        Parameters:
        appendable - appendable to add value's string representation to
        value - the value to describe
        maxCount - limits the elements to be added to the appendable; a negative value denotes unlimited - it is recommended to use DescriberProperties.UNLIMITED; the maxCount parameter does not promise any length of the appended String but should denote a limit the String representation for large objects; maxCount typically refers to list or array elements
